name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

prompt:
Casimir wants to determine whether the pattern he devised can be duplicated using ticks that meet the previously mentioned size constraints. The task at hand involves validating if the predefined criteria for tick dimensions align with the pattern's replication requirements.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

def validate_tick_patterns(t: int, test_cases: list[tuple[int, int, int, list[str]]]) -> list[str]:
    """Validate tick patterns based on given constraints.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (list[tuple[int, int, int, list[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the field.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the field.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - field (list[str]): List of strings representing the field.

    Returns:
        list[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark tick centers
        tick_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible tick centers
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                is_tick_center = True
                for d in range(1, k + 1):
                    if field[i - d][j - d] != '*' or field[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                        is_tick_center = False
                        break
                if is_tick_center:
                    tick_center[i][j] = True

        # Mark the field with ticks
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if tick_center[i][j]:
                    for d in range(k + 1):
                        field[i - d] = field[i - d][:j - d] + '.' + field[i - d][j - d + 1:]
                        field[i - d] = field[i - d][:j + d] + '.' + field[i - d][j + d + 1:]

        # Check if the field is completely marked
        is_valid = all(field[i][j] == '.' for i in range(n) for j in range(m) if field[i][j] == '*')
        results.append("YES" if is_valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    """Main function to read input and output results."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = validate_tick_patterns(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def validate_tick_patterns(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Validate if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the field.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a '*' can be part of a valid tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the field
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this '*' can be the center of a tick of size k
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            field[i - size][j - size] == '*' and field[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a tick
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j - s] = True
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Validate the field
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    # Output interface
    results = validate_tick_patterns(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def validate_tick_patterns(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Validate tick patterns based on given constraints.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the field.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark tick centers
        tick_centers = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible tick centers
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    valid_tick = True
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if field[i - d][j - d] != '*' or field[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        tick_centers[i][j] = True

        # Mark all cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if tick_centers[i][j]:
                    d = 0
                    while i - d >= 0 and j - d >= 0 and j + d < m and field[i - d][j - d] == '*' and field[i - d][j + d] == '*':
                        marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                        marked[i - d][j + d] = True
                        d += 1

        # Validate if all '*' in the field are marked
        valid_field = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid_field = False
                    break
            if not valid_field:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid_field else "NO")

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    results = validate_tick_patterns(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List

def validate_tick_patterns(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Validate if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the field.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark the positions that can be part of a valid tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible tick centers
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                field[i - size][j - size] == '*' and field[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If a valid tick of at least size k is found, mark the positions
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j - s] = True
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Validate the field
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    # Output interface
    results = validate_tick_patterns(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the field.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark the cells that can be part of a tick
        tick_grid = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    can_form_tick = True
                    for size in range(1, k + 1):
                        if (i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m or
                                field[i - size][j - size] != '*' or field[i - size][j + size] != '*'):
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break
                    if can_form_tick:
                        # Mark the cells that are part of the tick
                        tick_grid[i][j] = True
                        for size in range(1, k + 1):
                            tick_grid[i - size][j - size] = True
                            tick_grid[i - size][j + size] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the field are part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not tick_grid[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append('YES' if valid else 'NO')

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def validate_tick_patterns(test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Validate if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        test_cases (List[tuple]): A list of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the field.

    Returns:
        List[str]: A list of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []
    
    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a copy of the field to mark valid tick positions
        marked_field = [['.' for _ in range(m)] for _ in range(n)]
        
        # Iterate over each cell in the field
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with center at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            field[i - size][j - size] == '*' and field[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break
                    
                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the tick positions
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            marked_field[i - s][j - s] = '*'
                            marked_field[i - s][j + s] = '*'
        
        # Compare marked_field with the original field to determine if the pattern is valid
        is_valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and marked_field[i][j] != '*':
                    is_valid = False
                    break
            if not is_valid:
                break
        
        results.append("YES" if is_valid else "NO")
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))
    
    # Output interface
    results = validate_tick_patterns(test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def validate_tick_patterns(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Validate if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the field.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the field.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - field (List[str]): Field matrix represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a matrix to track if a '*' can be part of a valid tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over the field to check for possible ticks
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this '*' can be the center of a tick of size k
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           field[i - size][j - size] == '*' and field[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1
                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the positions as part of a tick
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j - s] = True
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Validate the field
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    # Output interface
    results = validate_tick_patterns(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List

def validate_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Validate if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the field.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the field
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this cell can be the center of a tick of size k
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           field[i - size][j - size] == '*' and field[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a tick
                    if size > k:
                        for s in range(size):
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j - s] = True
                            can_be_tick[i - s][j + s] = True

        # Validate if all '*' in the field can be part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    # Output interface
    results = validate_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the pattern can be replicated using ticks of specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the field.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the field.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - field (List[str]): The field represented as a list of strings.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, field in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark valid tick centers
        valid_tick_centers = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick of size k
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if field[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed
                    can_form_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if field[i - d][j - d] != '*' or field[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break
                    if can_form_tick:
                        valid_tick_centers[i][j] = True
                        # Mark the cells that are part of the tick
                        for d in range(1, k + 1):
                            valid_tick_centers[i - d][j - d] = True
                            valid_tick_centers[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Validate the entire field
        is_valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if field[i][j] == '*' and not valid_tick_centers[i][j]:
                    is_valid = False
                    break
            if not is_valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if is_valid else "NO")

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        field = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, field))

    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
